Do you know anything about the fisheries that are downstream like Goldcliff?
No, I don't know a huge amount about them really. They were mainly basket fisheries.
And by that do you mean like putcher?
Putchers, yeah, conical baskets originally made from willow and hazel.
There will be hundreds of baskets in some ranks set to a scaffold usually facing the ebb tide.
They aren't set on a slight incline and the salmon swim in, they've got no reverse gear, they can't get back out.
The tide goes out and the fisherman comes along and collects the catch.
The ones in sort of recent times, not recent times, in memory then, the Undy putcher rank, the Porton putcher rank and the Goldcliff putcher rank.
There's three main ones.
And they know that the Undy rank was, what happened there was that the number of baskets was reduced down to 150 baskets,
perhaps in the 60s by the Natural Rivers Authority and it became uneconomic to use.
Porton, I'm not sure when that closed, but Goldcliff closed in 1995, bought out by Anglin Interests and the Environment Agency, but closed down, all never to return.
The other basket fishery was not salmon fishery, it was putts or kipes.
They were medieval baskets fished in groups of perhaps six, seven, eight and they were used to catch white fish made from hazeln and willow as well in three sections.
I can't remember the four wheel, I can't remember the names of them, but a kite or putt was used to catch white fish and shrimp.
Same thing applies with face the ebb tide, the fish pushed in by the tide and then the fish will come along at low tide when they're dry and take the end basket off and take the catcher.
We found baskets buried in the clay that are kipes and putts or these things at hundreds if not a thousand years old on the estuary.
Just amazing. Did you ever lay eel traps on the reams?
No, no, no. We've never trapped fish in the reams, but as a kid we would catch stiltbacks and eels and newts and the like in the reams. They seemed to be a lot cleaner back then.
But I've never seen locally anybody trap fish like that.
We used to fish, as kids we'd go fishing in the in the in the pills we used to call them sort of San Pierre pill was a good one, sort of very natural sort of pill.

And that involved walking out to rocky areas in the estuary with a bar, iron bar and poking it under a rock, rattling the rock about and then hopefully there'd be an eel under there.
And he'd come out and you'd take it and kill it at the table.

There's certain things you look for all the time.
When you're fishing out in Gruggy, which is mid-channel, close to the main shipping channel.
You can get cut off quite easily.
When you're on foot, you're going to drown if you don't come back at the right time.
So what you're looking for is the tide rising in the shipping channel.
